scientific_summary: High arousal states benefit from parasympathetic activation and cognitive defusion techniques (Porges, 2011; Hayes, 2016).

immediate.title: 4-4-6 paced breathing
instructions: Inhale gently through the nose for four counts.
Hold your breath softly for four counts without tensing.
Exhale through pursed lips for six counts, letting your shoulders drop.

evidence.summary: Extended exhalation stimulates vagal tone and lowers sympathetic arousal.

immediate.title: Cool water face reset
instructions: Splash cool water on your face or hold a cool compress to your cheeks for 30 seconds.
Focus on the temperature shift and the sensation against your skin.
Repeat up to three times while noticing your breathing slow.

evidence.summary: Temperature change activates the dive reflex, quickly reducing physiological arousal.

immediate.title: 5-4-3-2-1 grounding
instructions: Name five things you can see, four you can touch, three you can hear, two you can smell, one you can taste.
Keep breaths steady while moving through each sense.
Repeat the cycle once more, noticing any drop in intensity.

evidence.summary: Sensory grounding interrupts overwhelm cycles and restores present-moment focus.

short_term.title: Name the thought distortion
instructions: Write down the loudest thought you're experiencing.
Label the distortion (e.g., catastrophizing, mind reading, all-or-nothing).
Rewrite the thought in a balanced way that fits the facts.

evidence.source: Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology, 2014
evidence.summary: Cognitive restructuring reduces emotional intensity by reframing automatic thoughts.

short_term.title: Send a grounding message
instructions: Text a trusted person one sentence describing how you're feeling.
Ask for a simple response: 'Can you remind me of one calm moment we shared?'.
Note their reply and write one gratitude sentence in your journal.

evidence.summary: Brief social support interactions buffer stress responses and increase perceived safety.

short_term.title: Priority triad
instructions: List every task on your mind; star the three that truly must happen today.
Break the first starred task into a 15-minute starter action.
Schedule or begin the starter action immediately, defer or delegate the rest.

evidence.summary: Focusing on a small priority set reduces decision fatigue and overwhelm.

long_term.title: Weekly values check-in
instructions: List three core values guiding your week (e.g., compassion, steadiness, creativity).
Write one action you took (or could take) that aligns with each value.
Note how acting on that value shifts your emotional baseline.

evidence.summary: Values clarification improves resilience and reduces emotional avoidance (ACT framework).

long_term.title: Sleep hygiene anchor
instructions: Set a consistent wind-down alarm 30 minutes before bed.
Dim lights, reduce screens, and journal one calming intention for tomorrow.
Use a gentle stretch or progressive muscle relaxation to signal bedtime.

evidence.summary: Structured wind-down routines improve sleep quality and reduce emotional volatility.

long_term.title: Capacity review
instructions: Audit recurring commitments and rate each from 1-5 on energy cost and meaning.
Identify one commitment to pause or renegotiate this month.
Document how the freed capacity will support balance.

evidence.summary: Regular workload audits and boundary adjustments reduce chronic overwhelm and burnout.

friend_support.title: Support triad
instructions: Ask your friend to name one feeling, one need, one step they can take.
Reflect each back to ensure they feel heard.
Offer to assist with the next step (co-working, reminder, break).

evidence.source: Feeney & Collins, Personality and Social Psychology Review, 2015
evidence.summary: Responsive support that validates and collaborates lowers overwhelm and boosts resilience.

friend_support.title: Co-schedule breathing room
instructions: Review calendars together and block shared downtime or breaks.
Set check-in reminders to ensure the downtime happens.
Celebrate keeping the appointment to reinforce the habit.

evidence.source: Reis & Gable, Current Opinion in Psychology, 2015
evidence.summary: Coordinated self-care plans with partners enhance adherence and emotional outcomes.

self_repair.title: Repair after shutting down
instructions: Explain the overwhelm trigger and the withdrawal behavior ("I went silent during our call").
Acknowledge how it affected them and express appreciation for their patience.
Share one regulation tool you will use next time and invite their support.

evidence.source: Johnson & Greenman, Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, 2013
evidence.summary: Emotionally focused repair conversations increase security after overwhelm-driven withdrawal.

self_repair.title: Set overwhelm boundaries
instructions: Identify one frequent overwhelm trigger caused by others' expectations.
Draft a boundary statement that includes what you can offer instead.
Communicate the boundary and agree on a follow-up review date.

evidence.summary: Clear interpersonal boundaries reduce recurrent overwhelm and role overload.
